intro: Acaena argentea var. contracta, commonly known as silver burr or silver weed, is a low-growing perennial plant native to New Zealand. It features dense, mat-forming foliage with silvery-gray leaves that are covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, spiny burrs that are adapted for seed dispersal by attaching to animal fur. It thrives in dry, sunny environments and is often found in disturbed soils. Its botanical characteristics make it both an ornamental plant and a potential weed in certain regions.

Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones within South America.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena argentea var. contracta was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive silver foliage and compact growth habit. Despite its aesthetic appeal, it has become invasive in some areas, outcompeting native vegetation. The plant thrives in a variety of soil types and can tolerate both full sun and partial shade. Its spread has raised concerns among conservationists due to its potential to disrupt local ecosystems.
